I really enjoyed the few minutes I got to speak with you guys at worlds. My team will learn a lot from digging through this documentation. We’ve been floating the idea of doing an off-season interpretation of this robot for a design/build project

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":88,"updated_at":"2024-05-10T14:28:14.289Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":1731,"readers_count":1730,"score":441.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":465867,"topic_slug":"team-2056-op-robotics-2024-technical-binder-release","display_username":"John Fogarty","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12688,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Off to California I go..."},"post_url":"/t/team-2056-op-robotics-2024-technical-binder-release/465867/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3383661,"name":"Phil Szymanowski","username":"Cyberphil","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberphil/{size}/161083_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-10T14:21:24.506Z","cooked":"

The technical binder is cool, but that 166 page drawing package is absolutely insane. It has assembly instructions for every part in the process, including aligning timing pulleys properly, specific material and finish callouts, details on how COTS parts get modified, position of sponsor logos on panels, post-processing instructions, every single COTS component supplier and their respective part numbers, and so much more.

I’ll be honest, I have never seen this level of assembly detail in manufacturing drawings ever, including all of my professional experience.

If you skipped the drawing package, go back and give it a look. This is an absolute masterclass on what mechanical drawings can be.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":88,"updated_at":"2024-05-10T14:22:41.349Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":11,"reads":1660,"readers_count":1659,"score":1377.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":465867,"topic_slug":"team-2056-op-robotics-2024-technical-binder-release","display_username":"Phil Szymanowski","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":64}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":10874,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 272 (Cyber Crusaders), FTC 23598 (Robotic Pretzles)"},"post_url":"/t/team-2056-op-robotics-2024-technical-binder-release/465867/8","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":58},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"open_mouth","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":65,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3383665,"name":"","username":"Akash_Rastogi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/akash_rastogi/{size}/169937_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-10T14:25:21.977Z","cooked":"

Question on a lot of the parts you hex broached on your own to reduce system backlash - was this due to the COTS part not being available or because your broaching is actually holding tighter tolerances than what most vendors provide? If the latter, what broach are you using?

Or is that more that your sprockets and hubs were all wider to accommodate more surface area like some of the hubs mentioned? Do you still add shims if that is the case?

In general seems you have more custom machined parts for torque transfer than I anticipated. What kinds of fabrication resources does 2056 have?

For the climber - do you mind linking to the quick exhausts mentioned?

Thanks in advance!

Akash_Rastogi:

What kinds of fabrication resources does 2056 have?

That’s listed in the Tech Binder. (page 22)

Thank you for sharing both of these documents, very interesting software setup! I’m just curious is there any specific reason for using the Timed-Based framework over the Command-Based framework?

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":88,"updated_at":"2024-05-10T15:46:26.033Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":1412,"readers_count":1411,"score":357.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":465867,"topic_slug":"team-2056-op-robotics-2024-technical-binder-release","display_username":"Visvam Rajesh","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65755,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3637 Team President"},"post_url":"/t/team-2056-op-robotics-2024-technical-binder-release/465867/13","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3383805,"name":"Dan Langdon","username":"woodworker2001","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/bbe5ce/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-10T16:03:52.341Z","cooked":"

Obviously can’t speak for them but we always have tighter fit with parts we broach versus cots pre broached gears.

Akash_Rastogi:

because your broaching is actually holding tighter tolerances than what most vendors provide?

This is likely due to most vendors adding additional tolerances to account for shafts being not low tolerance and to make it easier to assemble. If you make it yourself you can likely achieve much tighter tolerances.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":88,"updated_at":"2024-05-10T16:13:11.497Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":1382,"readers_count":1381,"score":306.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":465867,"topic_slug":"team-2056-op-robotics-2024-technical-binder-release","display_username":"Ankur Raghavan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50601,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5⁵-4⁴"},"post_url":"/t/team-2056-op-robotics-2024-technical-binder-release/465867/15","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3383865,"name":"Zachary","username":"Zatack7","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zatack7/{size}/175437_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-10T16:29:03.666Z","cooked":"

In my limited experience with using our 1/2” hex broach, it makes bores much tighter than anything COTS, but unless you’ve got a good, repeatable setup (which I’m sure 2056 does), you’ll end up with some axial (I think that’s the right term) runout.

Edit: I have been informed that the term here is radial runout, not axial runout.

2056 is perpetually the team I’m most likely to say “we could and should have built that robot but didn’t” about. 2024 was no different. I absolutely love the simplicity and robustness of this design. This CAD package is next-level quality, too.

","post_number":20,"post_type":1,"posts_count":88,"updated_at":"2024-05-10T23:21:59.464Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":18,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":1325,"readers_count":1324,"score":1070.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":465867,"topic_slug":"team-2056-op-robotics-2024-technical-binder-release","display_username":"Matt Golman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7167,"username":"tyron256","name":"Saber_8871","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tyron256/{size}/177261_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":53}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9246,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mechanical/Strategy Mentor | 1678"},"post_url":"/t/team-2056-op-robotics-2024-technical-binder-release/465867/20","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":50},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":53,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3384292,"name":"Balraj Singh ","username":"Khalsa","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/khalsa/{size}/263572_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-11T00:31:22.371Z","cooked":"
john3928:

Gearbox
…all gears including the motor pinion were bonded to the
shaft using retaining compound to eliminate backlash.

Loctite?

Yes we use Loctite 609 to fill the gaps in the bore.

mercified:

did you use anything besides shim tape to reduce backlash on your shoulder gearbox?

We do not use any shim tape to reduce backlash.

Akash_Rastogi:

a lot of the parts you hex broached on your own to reduce system backlash - was this due to the COTS part not being available or because your broaching is actually holding tighter tolerances than what most vendors provide? If the latter, what broach are you using?

Or is that more that your sprockets and hubs were all wider to accommodate more surface area like some of the hubs mentioned? Do you still add shims if that is the case?

Every measure to prevent backlash started in 2023 with our double-jointed arm, the low backlash was vital for its motion and precision, last year we used a lot of COTS gears we had in inventory and their hex interface was very loose for something like a long arm.

This year we also needed this kind of precision when shooting into the speaker at range so we took many of the same measures, we also used new gears this year from WCP and their hex bore was significantly tighter that alone was a huge improvement but we took that extra measure to Loctite the gear on to the shaft making a zero-backlash fit.

We broached our own sprocket and made a gear hub for the final stage in the gearbox for the high load and to facilitate a zero-backlash fit. In the case of the hub that is bolted to the gear we machine it to be about 1" long which gives it much more surface area compared to the 1/2" deep bore of a normal gear preventing premature wear, it’s not really practical for us to machine or package a sprocket that is 1" long it’s only 1/2 an inch long but it’s easy enough to just replace once or twice a season once it begins to wears.

Picture of the gear hub assembly:

image869×753 98.1 KB

image701×642 77.2 KB

Akash_Rastogi:

what broach are you using?

Our broach was purchased 15 years ago from McMaster-Carr. It being old and worn is the main reason for it being basically a push-fit on the shaft so we don’t use any shim tape or Loctite with the broached hubs and sprockets.

Although all of these backlash prevention measures are a fair amount of work it makes the arm control incredibly simple, precise and smooth.

Zatack7:

unless you’ve got a good, repeatable setup (which I’m sure 2056 does)

Our setup is fairly simple we use a decent arbour press but we take our time and are careful when aligning the broach and we have had no issues with any runout. It is really important that the initial bore is concentric with gear or sprocket and we always drill the bore undersized and use a reamer after.

barrel:

I’m just curious is there any specific reason for using the Timed-Based framework over the Command-Based framework?

We haven’t looked much into command-based programming but timed-based programming works effectively for us so we don’t see a reason to switch.

Akash_Rastogi:

For the climber - do you mind linking to the quick exhausts mentioned?

We get these from Automation Direct.
